The Elder Sālamaṇḍapī’s Birth Story
Having entered the Sāla forest,
my hermitage was well-made;
Covered with Sāla flowers,
I lived in the wilderness at that time.
The Fortunate Piyadassī,
the Self-Made, the Foremost Person;
The Buddha, who desired solitude,
went to the Sāla forest.
Having left the hermitage,
I went to the open air;
Searching for roots and fruits,
I wandered in the forest at that time.
There I saw the Buddha,
Piyadassī, of great fame;
Well-seated, attained to concentration,
shining in the great forest.
Having placed four sticks,
above the Buddha,
I made a well-made pavilion,
and covered it with Sāla flowers.
Having held it for seven days,
the pavilion covered with Sāla flowers;
Having gladdened my mind there,
I worshipped the Buddha, the Best.
At that time the Fortunate One,
having arisen from concentration;
Looking a plough’s length ahead,
sat down, the Foremost of Men.
A disciple named Varuna,
To the Teacher Piyadassin;
With a hundred thousand of the vasī,
He approached the leader of the world.
The Fortunate One Piyadassin,
The world’s chief, the best of men,
Sitting in the midst of the Community of monks,
The Victor made a smile appear.
Anuruddha, the attendant,
of the Teacher Piyadassin,
Having arranged his robe over one shoulder,
asked the Great Sage:
‘What is the reason, Fortunate One,
for the Teacher’s smile?
When there is a reason,
why did the Teacher make a smile appear?’
‘The young man who for seven days
held up a covering of Sāla leaves for me,
Remembering his deed,
I made a smile appear.
I do not see the opportunity,
where merit will be made manifest;
In the world of the gods or among men,
the opportunity is not available.
For one who dwells in the world of the gods,
endowed with meritorious deeds,
As far as the assembly of that (young man)
will be covered with Sāla leaves.
There, with divine dances,
songs, and music,
Always being happy, at peace,
he will be endowed with meritorious deeds.’
As long as the assembly is there,
it will be fragrant with sweet scents;
And a shower of Sāla flowers
will rain down for that long.🔽When he passes away from there,
that human will come to the human realm;
Here too the Sāla tree’s shade
will last for all time.
Here, with dancing and singing,
accompanied by cymbals and drums,
will always surround me;
this is the fruit of worshipping the Buddha.🔽And as the sun rises,
it will rain down on the Sāla tree;
Connected with meritorious deeds,
it will rain down at all times.
For eighteen hundred eons,
born in the Okkāka family,
with the clan name Gotama,
a Teacher will appear in the world.
His heir in the Dhamma,
born from his own heart,
having fully understood all the pollutants,
will be extinguished, without pollutants.
When he attains the Dhamma,
there will be a Sāla tree’s shade;
when the funeral pyre is burning,
that will be the covering there.’
Having extolled the ripening,
the Great Seer Piyadassī
taught the Dhamma to the assembly,
I was satisfied with the Dhamma’s growth.
